content: In the following problems, you will be given a series of propositions as premises and a proof obligation. The premises are in the form '(1) xxx. (2) xxx. (3) xxx. ...', and the proof obligation is in the form 'Prove: (n) xxx.' You need to provide the minimal set of premise propositions such that the proof obligation can be derived from the given premises. You should present the result in the form '(1),(2),(3),...->(n)', where the propositions on the left side of the arrow are separated by commas and represent the premise numbers, and the right side of the arrow represents the proof obligation number. Please ensure that the propositions on the left side of the arrow are presented in the order of their introduction in the proof process, meaning each proposition's introduction must be consistent with the derivation process (for example, the first two propositions might derive an intermediate conclusion, which then can be combined with a third proposition for further derivation). The answer should only be in the form '(1),(2),(3),...->(n)'.(For each problem, you need to first present three related but not identical problems, along with a description of each problem and its solution. Finally, provide the answer to the original problem in the form of "Therefore, the final answer is: ".)

Premises: [(1) Lempuses are sterpuses. (2) Lempuses are jompuses. (3) Every sterpus is not opaque. (4) Sterpuses are rompuses. (5) Every lempus is earthy. (6) Each rompus is shy. (7) Each sterpus is a numpus. (8) Each shumpus is mean. (9) Each jompus is red. (10) Shumpuses are impuses. (11) Stella is a shumpus. (12) Stella is a lempus.] Prove: (13) Stella is not opaque.

Problem 1: 
Premises: [(1) All A are B. (2) All A are C. (3) All B are not D. (4) B are E. (5) All A are F. (6) All E are G. (7) All H are I. (8) All J are K. (9) All L are M. (10) All I are N. (11) P is H. (12) P is A.] Prove: (13) P is not D.

Problem 2: 
Premises: [(1) X is Y. (2) X is Z. (3) All Y are not Q. (4) Y is W. (5) X is R. (6) Z is S. (7) M is N. (8) O is P. (9) T is U. (10) N is V. (11) Q is Z. (12) U is X.] Prove: (13) M is not Q.

Problem 3: 
Premises: [(1) P are Q. (2) P are R. (3) All Q are not S. (4) Q are T. (5) P are U. (6) R are V. (7) W are X. (8) Y are Z. (9) A are B. (10) V are C. (11) D are P. (12) D are Q.] Prove: (13) A are not S.

Therefore, the final answer is: (11),(12)->(13)

Premises: [(0) Every mother has a son. (1) Lempuses are sterpuses. (2) Lempuses are jompuses. (3) Every sterpus is not opaque. (4) Sterpuses are rompuses. (5) Every lempus is earthy. (6) Each rompus is shy. (7) Each sterpus is a numpus. (8) Each shumpus is mean. (9) Each jompus is red. (10) Shumpuses are impuses. (11) Stella is a shumpus. (12) Stella is a lempus.] Prove: (13) Stella is not opaque.

Problem 1: 
Premises: [(0) All A have B. (1) C are D. (2) C are E. (3) All D are not F. (4) D are G. (5) All C are H. (6) Each G is I. (7) Each D is a J. (8) Each K is L. (9) Each M is N. (10) K are O. (11) P is K. (12) P is C.] Prove: (13) P is not F.

Problem 2: 
Premises: [(0) All X have Y. (1) X are Z. (2) Y are not A. (3) X are B. (4) C are D. (5) E are F. (6) G are H. (7) I are J. (8) K are L. (9) M are N. (10) O are P. (11) Q is O. (12) Q is X.] Prove: (13) Q is not A.

Problem 3: 
Premises: [(0) All R have S. (1) T are U. (2) T are V. (3) All U are not W. (4) U are X. (5) All T are Y. (6) Each X is Z. (7) Each Y is a AA. (8) Each BB is CC. (9) DD are EE. (10) BB are FF. (11) GG is BB. (12) GG is T.] Prove: (13) DD are not W.

Therefore, the final answer is: (11),(12)->(13)
